instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 5V 0.08A
threads.message:
Uknown history looks like someone cleaned the board ultrasonically
No visible corrosion

Takes 5V and 0.08A looping to 0.00A every ~5 seconds

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.3V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V -- [COLOR=rgb(235, 107, 86)]EDIT: Available if i power from this port[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1.1V --[COLOR=rgb(235, 107, 86)] EDIT: 0V if powered from the other port[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UOC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V

Should i replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> due to missing 1.1V LDO or it can be something else?

[COLOR=rgb(235, 107, 86)]EDIT:
Not sure if any of these are related

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PHV_INT_XB_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0V[/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 5V 0.08A
threads.message:
1V1 LDO only appears on powered port.

Both USB-C ports have the same (pulsing) behaviour?
In such case, should be something else on the board.
Check for short on all secondary power supplies.
Looks like the board tries to starrt, but SMC stops it.
Try strating in SMC bypass mode.

What happens if battery and charger are both connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 5V 0.08A
threads.message:
Both USB ports have the same pulsing behavior on the amps usage.
I couldn't find short on any big caps or coils.
Is there an SMC on this one? It's a T2 model.
If the battery and the charger are both connected one port goes to 0.09A the other to 0.07A and they do not cycle.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 5V 0.08A
threads.message:
"If the battery and the charger are both connected one port goes to 0.09A the other to 0.07A and they do not cycle."
Does the board try to start in this case (pressing power button)?
USB meter still stuck in 5V?

Do you get all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages (on charger alone)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 5V 0.08A
threads.message:
The USB is still stuck at 5V
The board doesn't start.

Connecting to another MacBook to try and do DFU reset gives "Cannot use thunderbolt Accessory"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 5V 0.08A
threads.message:
Be sure to use same macOS as in T2 machine.
Read all the info about DFU.
Many people complained about entering to DFU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 5V 0.08A
threads.message:
I haven't had any luck with DFU yet, nor I know what OS is on the T2 machine as I bought it as is.
Any other suggestions?

Edit:
I forgot to add, sometimes (1 out of 7-8 connections) it will go to 19-20V with 0.08A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 5V 0.08A
threads.message:
T2 machine should have Catalina, or Big Sur installed.
But someone reported a Mac Mini from 2020 which came with Mojave from Apple.
Try all options...
